TAGS.acquisition: Concept lists related to studies on language acquisition
TAGS.annotated: Concept lists which contain further annotations which exceed the complexity of ranks
TAGS.areal: Concept lists designed for a specific linguistic area.
TAGS.basic: Concept lists which are supposed to represent the basic vocabulary.
TAGS.body parts: Concept lists which concentrate on body parts.
TAGS.documentation: Concept lists which serve to document one language or one language family.
TAGS.hihi: A list of highly reconstructable and highly retentive items (term from McMahon & McMahon 2005).
TAGS.historical: A list which is historically interesting, mostly referring to lists published before the 20th century.
TAGS.lolo: A list of less stable basic items, with low reconstructability and low retentiveness (term from McMahon & McMahon 2005).
TAGS.naming test: A list designed for a naming test in neurology or psycholinguistics to asses the linguistic capability of children and adults.
TAGS.proto-language: A list illustrating the concepts in a proto-language which can be reconstructed with high certainty.
TAGS.questionnaire: A questionnaire for linguistic field work.
TAGS.ranked: A list that shows items in a ranked order, and has one column reflecting the rank.
TAGS.sign language: A list which was designed to investigate sign languages.
TAGS.specific: A list that we deem specific, since it is not easy to compare with other lists in our sample.
TAGS.stable: A list that is supposed to represent the stable part of a larger list. Usually, the stable part has an unstable counterpart.
TAGS.ultra-stable: A usually very short list of the supposedly most stable concepts.
TAGS.unstable: A list that is supposed to represent the unstable part of a larger list. Usually has a stable counterpart.
